metadata.title: Role of nano-additive blended biodiesel on emission characteristics of the research diesel engine

sections.text:
ARTICLE HISTORY Received 6 September 2018 Accepted 30 January 2019
KEYWORDS Carbon Nano tube; emission analysis; biodiesel; neem oil; diesel engine

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Diesel engines are widely used engines for transportation and power generation across the world. Despite the high thermal efficiency, high torque capacity and less NOX emission they emit high HC, smoke, and CO emissions which creates great environmental concern. Ever increasing emission standards around the world have forced the researchers to explore newmethods or to improve existing methods to reduce these emissions. The engine manufacturer researchers are encouraged to search for emission control techniques and alternative fuel source to meet the fuel crisis and stringent emission regulation. In this context, biodiesel occupies a prominent position in the development of alternative fuel. Biodiesel is used as a neat or blended with diesel in compression ignition engines (Devarajan et al. 2017b). Biodiesel can be obtained when vegetable oil is chemically reacted with an alcohol to produce monoalkyl esters. In the process, glycerol is obtained as a co-product (Yuvarajan and Ramanan 2016a). Biodiesel comprises a number of fatty acid esters and generally classified as fatty acid methyl esters. The fatty acids vary in their carbon chain length and in the number of double bonds of carbon. In spite of several advantages of biodiesel such as biodegradation, non-toxicity, good lubricity, ecofriendly, and sustainability, it is not widely employed because of its higher viscosity (Prabhu and Venkata Ramanan 2018a), poor volatility (Selvam et al., 2013; Siva, Munuswamy, and Devarajan 2018) and lower heating value (Arunprasad and Balusamy 2018; Krupakaran, Hariprasad, and Gopalakrishna, 2018) which could reduce its combustion efficiency and leads to higher magnitude of NOx emission when used in engines (Kishore Pandian et al. 2017; Radhakrishnan et al. 2018a, 2018b). Many works have proved that by adding metal oxide nanoparticle to biodiesel reduces its NOx emission and improve its combustion characteristics (Vellaiyan, Subbiah, and Chockalingam 2019; Pandian, Ramakrishnan, and Devarajan 2017; Kishore Pandian et al. 2018; Yuvarajan, Ravikumar, and Babu 2016, Yuvarajan et al., 2018; Devarajan, Munuswamy, and Mahalingam 2018a, 2018b; Venkata Ramanan and Yuvarajan 2016). Metal-based additives result in improved evaporative rate and shortened delay period, which results in improved combustion and lower engine NOx emissions.Metal-based additives also provide the catalytic activity during the combustion process. Devarajan, Munuswamy, and Mahalingam (2018a) investigated the performance and emission characteristics of a diesel engine fuelled with AgO nanoparticle into biodiesel. Adding nanoparticle to diesel resulted in enhancement in flash and fire point. Moreover, nanoparticle reduced NOx emissions by 4.6% as compared to the neat biodiesel. Kishore Pandian et al. (2017) investigated the effect of titanium oxide nanopowder with neat biodiesel. Adding nanoparticle to biodiesel resulted in a 6.7% reduction in NOx emissions. Yuvarajan and Ramanan (2016) examined the effect of ferrofluid on biodiesel fuelled diesel engine and reported in the considerable reduction in CO, HC, and NOx emissions. Appavu and Venkata Ramanan (2018) examined the effect of cerium oxide as an additive in diesel fuel and found a 1.1%, 3.7%, and 4.2% reduction in NOx, CO, and smoke emissions, respectively. Anbarasu et al., (2015) studied the role of aluminumoxide as a fuel-borne additive in diesel and biodiesel blends. They reported a 1.8%, 3.3%, 3.9%, and 4.2% reduction in CO, Smoke, HC, and NOx, respectively, by adding aluminum oxide in diesel and biodiesel blends.
CONTACT Yuvarajan Devarajan dyuvarajan2@gmail.com Color versions of one or more of the figures in the article can be found online at www.tandfonline.com/ljge.
© 2019 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC
After a systematic literature review on the nanoparticles, it was found that Carbon Nanotubes (CNT) blending at different concentrations with neat biodiesel (B100) for diesel engine applications was not explored. There exists a research gap on utilizing neat neem biodiesel (NBD) as an alternative for diesel in an unmodified research diesel engine. Further, no detailed research work has been reported detailing the effect of CNT in NBD on their emissions patterns in an unmodified diesel engine. This work paves the way on investigating the effect of appending CNT nano-additive to NBD in powder form at 50 ppm and 100 ppm. CNT nanoparticle (CNT, alpha, 98+%) were mixed with NBD at 50 ppm (NBDCNT50) and 100 ppm (NBDCNT100) on mass basis using magnetic stirrer and ultrasonicator to ensure homogenous dispersion and to study the engine emission characteristics of an unaltered research diesel engine.

sections.heading: 2.1. Fuel preparation (NBD)
sections.text: NBD is prepared by base catalyzed transesterification process. Suitable arrangements were provided to control reaction temperature and stirring speed.Molar ratio of 6:1 (methanol to neem oil) and catalysts of 0.25% (wt/wt) to neem oil was used in transesterification process adapting standard procedure (Devarajan et al., 2017a, 2017b; Appavu, 2018; Devarajan 2018; Ganesan et al. 2018; Joy et al. 2017; Joy, Yuvarajan, and Beemkumar 2019; Mahalingam 2018; Radhakrishnan 2017). 500 g sample of mustard oil in the reactor is heated till 60°C. A measured quantity of solution containing catalysts dissolved inmethanol is then added andmixed at a constant stirring speed of 340 rpm for 45 min. This ensured uniform reactivity of solution and accelerated the reaction rate. The mixture is then allowed to cool in the vessel yielding two distinct layers of ester and glycerol. Ester is then separated andwashed thricewithwater and dried for further analysis. The ester thus obtained following conventional procedure is referred to as NBD.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis and characterization of CNT
sections.text: CNT nano-additive was procured from sigma-Aldrich at a purity of 99.4%. The particle size of CNT was found to be 50 nm. The average surface area of CNT was found to be 504 m2/gm. X-ray diffraction was employed to study the crystalline phase of CNT. It was clear that CNT with the particle size 50 nm will not provide any restrictions in fuel flow through the injection system.

sections.heading: 2.3. Modified fuel preparations (NBDCNT50 and NBDCNT100)
sections.text: CNT nanoparticle were mixed with NBD at a different dosage levels of 50 and 100 ppm on mass basis. Ultrasonicator with a frequency of 60–100 kHz is employed to ensure homogenous dispersion. Fuel containing CNT nanoparticle is also stirred using magnetic agitator for 60 min at a speed of 450 rpm in atmospheric conditions to improve the bonding between CNT and fuel (Devarajan et al. 2016; Devarajan and Munuswamy 2016). The fuel comprising NBD with 50 ppm of CNT nano-additive is expressed as NBDCNT50 and the fuel comprising NBD with 100 ppm of nano-additive is expressed as NBDCNT100. The modified fuels were found stable for 40 days without any sedimentation of CNT nano-additive. The addition of CNT nano-additive has a significant impact on fuel properties such as density, viscosity, flash point, cloud point, pour point, calorific value, and cetane index. The prepared biodiesel blend along with the nano additive can be suitably used in a diesel engine without any modifications. The properties of various fuels are listed in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.4. Engine test setup and procedure
sections.text:
In this work, a single cylinder and four-stroke diesel engine of Kirloskar make (Model No. 10.101–2) was used. Figure 1 shows the experimental setup with the modified intake manifold. The intake manifold was modified with a venturi setup. Three kinds of venturi setup are used here with varying the ratios of outer
Figure 1. Venturi (left) and the experimental setup (right).
and inner diameter while maintaining the length fixed. Three venturi diameter ratios were used in the work with 1.25, 1.50, and 1.75. Venturi diameter ratio of 1 (regular pipe of the same diameter) was considered as the reference. The venturi setup is threaded into the intake manifold so that the outer to inner diameter can be varied. The engine’s power rating and maximum speed are 3.7 KW and 1500 rpm, respectively. The engine specifications are detailed in Table 2. The engine is connected to eddy current dynamometer for the load to be applied. The load conditions (0%, 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100% of the full load rating) were considered in the experiment. The operating parameters were adjusted electronically with a control panel attached to the engine. It can be operated through a display unit attached to the control panel. The display unit could be used for displaying the values of those parameters. The exhaust emissions such as HC, CO, CO2, and NOx were measured using AVL Di-gas analyzer and the smoke opacity was measured using AVL 437 smoke meter. Table 3 indicates the Range and accuracy details of exhaust gas analyzer.

sections.heading: 2.5. Uncertainty analysis
3.1. Nitrogen oxides emission
sections.text: Nitrogen is formed by oxidation of nitrogen in the air during combustion at very high temperature. The high temperature in the combustion chamber and surplus availability of oxygen are the cause for NOx formation (Devarajan and Venkata Ramanan 2016). The NOx emission characteristics of the NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 and diesel at various loads are depicted in Figure 2. The NBD and CNT blends exhibit more amount of NOx than diesel due to higher oxygen availability that resulted in high combustion temperature and higher NOX emissions (Appavu and Venkata Ramanan 2018). NBD exhibits 13.2% higher NOx emission than diesel at full load condition. CNT inclusion in NBD reduces the NOx emission at all loading conditions. Adding of CNT at 50 and 100 ppm to NBD reduces NOx emissions by 6.3% and 9.2%, respectively at all loads. The possible reason for the reduction in NOX emissions is due to enhancement in thermal conductivity and latent heat evaporation of fuel by adding nanoparticles to it (Arulprakasajothi et al. 2018a, 2018b). Further, CNT inclusion improved the cetane number, surface area–volume ratio, and heat transfer rate of NBD. The NOX emissions recorded for NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 and diesel are 13.2, 12.5, 12.1, and 10.8 g/ kWh, respectively, at peak load.

sections.heading: 3.2. Hydrocarbon emission
sections.text:
Air and fuel mixing rate have a major role in HC emission. If the mixture is too lean, autoignition of fuel does not take place and result in unburned emission. Meanwhile, if the mixture is too rich, HC remains unburned because of incomplete mixing
(Arunprasad and Balusamy 2018). The HC emission characteristics of the NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 and diesel at various loads are shown in Figure 3. NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 exhibit lower HC emissions than diesel at all loads. The amount of oxygen available in NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 for combustion is adequate causing effective combustion and lower HC emissions than diesel (Arul Gnana Dhas et al., 2018). The inclusion of CNT at 50 and 100 ppm to NBD reduce HC emissions by 5.1% and 6.7%, respectively at all loads. This is due to the positive effect of CNT, which acts as oxidation catalysts, lowers the carbon combustion activation temperature, and improving the oxidation of NBD (Basha and Anand 2011). The other justification for lower HC emissions for NBDCNT50 and NBDCNT100 is due to shorter ignition delay and secondary atomization leading to enhanced combustion and reduced HC emission (Devarajan and Madhavan, 2017). The HC emissions recorded for NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 and diesel are 0.36, 0.31, 0.29, and 0.42 g/kWh, respectively, at peak load. V- replace as NBDCNT100 in below figure legend

sections.heading: 3.3. Carbon monoxide emission
sections.text:
Recombination reaction will be partial and result in incomplete oxidation of CO if there is a lack of oxidants or short residence time or low gas temperature. Oxidation of CO takes place in recombination reaction between CO and different oxidants present during combustion (Mahalingam et al. 2018; Pandian et al. 2018, 2017). The CO emission characteristics of the NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 and diesel at various loads are depicted in Figure 4. CO emissions for diesel are higher than NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 at all loads. This is due to higher oxygen content in NBD, CNT blends which promotes oxidation reaction, and replicates lower CO emissions (Karthikeyan, Elango, and Prathima 2016). The inclusion of CNT at 50 and 100 ppm to NBD reduces CO emissions by 4.2% and 5.8%, respectively at all loads. This is due to the positive effect of CNT that undergoes catalytic oxidation reaction and improving the mixing rate of NBD with available air during combustion (Vellaiyan, Subbiah, and Chockalingam
2019). Further, NBDCNT50 and NBDCNT100 generates lower ignition delay and causing complete oxidation in the premixed burning rate. The CO emissions recorded for NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 and diesel are 3.4, 2.9, 2.7, and 3.8 g/kWh, respectively, at peak load.

sections.heading: 3.4. Carbon dioxide emission
sections.text: Higher CO2 emission indicates the complete combustion of fuel and it is always inversely proportional to CO emission (Murugan and Appavu 2018; Pandian, Ramakrishnan, and Devarajan 2017). The CO2 emission characteristics of the NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 and diesel at various loads are shown in Figure 5. NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 exhibit higher CO2 emissions than diesel at all loads. The amount of oxygen available in NBD,NBDCNT50, andNBDCNT100 for combustion is adequate causing effective combustion and higher CO2 emissions than diesel (Prabhu and Venkata Ramanan, 2018b). The inclusion of CNT at 50 and 100 ppm to NBD increases the CO2 emissions by 6.8% and 7.9%, respectively, at all loads. Better air-fuel mixing and heat transfer rate, and improved catalytic activity enhance the CO2 emission of NBDCNT50 and NBDCNT100 (Vellaiyan, Subbiah, and Chockalingam 2018a, 2018b). The CO2 emissions recorded for NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 and diesel are 7.1, 7.5, 7.9, and 5.8 g/kWh, respectively, at peak load.

sections.heading: 3.5. Smoke opacity
sections.text:
The graphical demonstration of smoke opacity of NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 and diesel is depicted in Figure 6. Smoke emissions for diesel are higher than NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 at all loads. This is due to higher oxygen content in NBD, CNT blends which promotes oxidation reaction, and replicates lower smoke emissions (Prabhu and Venkata Ramanan 2018a; Ravikumar and Saravanan 2016). The inclusion of CNT at 50 and 100 ppm to NBD reduces smoke emissions by 6.3% and 7.8%, respectively. Addition of CNT to NBD has resulted in shortened ignition delay, better evaporation, and improved ignition characteristics (Senthilkumar et al., 2018). In addition, due to the presence of surplus oxygen in CNT, there is
a significant enhancement in the oxidation of carbon and result in the reduction of smoke emission (Sudalaimuthu et al. 2018; Vellaiyan, Subbiah, and Chockalingam 2019). The smoke opacity in % recorded for NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 and diesel are 1.4, 1.1, 0.9, and 1. 5, respectively, at peak load.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
Single-cylinder research engine was fueled with NBD, NBDCNT50, NBDCNT100 (metal-based additive) and diesel.
Emission characteristics of the test fuels have been analyzed by comparing with the neat baseline diesel fuel. The major findings of this work are detailed below:
● Base-catalyzed transesterification technique was employed for the production of biodiesel. ● The physicochemical properties of NBD, NBDCNT50, and NBDCNT100 are at par with ASTM standards and these fuels can be used in existing diesel engine without any modification. ● The NBD emits 4.8% higher NOx emission compared to diesel at peak load condition and CNT nanoparticle inclusion at 100 ppm promotes 9.2% lower NOx compared to NBD. ● The Overall HC and CO emissions are 6.8% and 4.7% lower for NBD compared to diesel. CNT addition at 100 ppm further reduces the HC and CO emissions by 6.7% and 5.9%, respectively, compared to NBD. ● The magnitude of CO2 emission in NBD is 6.6% higher than diesel at peak load condition. The CNT inclusion with NBD further increases the CO2 emission due to complete combustion. ● The smoke emissions of NBD is 2.1% lower than diesel at peak condition. The CNT inclusion at different ppm further reduces its smoke emissions by 7.8% when compared to NBD. ● No provisions were provided to remove the nanoparticle after the combustion from the exhaust system. However, the removal of nanoparticle in tailpipe after combustion is in the future scope of research.

referenceMentions.context: Biodiesel is used as a neat or blended with diesel in compression ignition engines (Devarajan et al. 2017b).

Fuel containing CNT nanoparticle is also stirred using magnetic agitator for 60 min at a speed of 450 rpm in atmospheric conditions to improve the bonding between CNT and fuel (Devarajan et al. 2016; Devarajan and Munuswamy 2016).

The uncertainties in various experimental results have been estimated using the method employed in different studies (Balan et al. 2018; Rathinam, Justin Abraham Baby, and Devarajan 2018; Devarajan et al., 2017a, 2017b).

The other justification for lower HC emissions for NBDCNT50 and NBDCNT100 is due to shorter ignition delay and secondary atomization leading to enhanced combustion and reduced HC emission (Devarajan and Madhavan, 2017).
Oxidation of CO takes place in recombination reaction between CO and different oxidants present during combustion (Mahalingam et al. 2018; Pandian et al. 2018, 2017).
Addition of CNT to NBD has resulted in shortened ignition delay, better evaporation, and improved ignition characteristics (Senthilkumar et al., 2018).

metadata.abstractText: The current experimental study is aimed to analyze the influence of single-walled Carbon Nano Tubes (CNT) on the emission characteristics of neem biodiesel-fueled (NBD-fueled) diesel engine and the results compared with conventional diesel. Experiments were conducted in a single-cylinder, 4-stroke, diesel engine with an eddy current dynamometer at a constant speed of 1500 rpm. Two samples of CNT are characterized and dispersed into 100% of the NBD in a mass fraction of 50 and 100 ppm using ultrasonicator, and the physicochemical properties were measured. Experimental results indicated that by adding CNT nanoparticles in NBD reduces its NOx, HC, CO, and smoke emission by 9.2%, 6.7%, 5.9%, and 7.8%, respectively, at all load conditions.
